questions.text: What type of radiation is used in mammography?
questions.solution:
There are two types of radiation generated by intereaction of electron with an atom. 1. Characteristic and 2. Bremsstrahlung Characteristic radiation is produced when a fast-moving electron collides with a K-shell electron, the electron in the K-shell is ejected (provided the energy of the incident electron is greater than the binding energy of K-shell electron) leaving behind a 'hole'. An outer shell electron fills this hole (from the L-shell, M-shell, etc. ) with an emission of a single x-ray photon, sometimes called a characteristic photon, with an energy level equivalent to the energy level difference between the outer and inner shell electron involved in the transition.Alternatively when the incident electron is displaced from it's pathway and emit's energy-is known as bremsstrahlung radiation.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medial imaging page 7

questions.text:
Arrange in proper sequence the following modalities on the basis of radiation exposure.
1. CXR
2. HRCT chest
3. Abdomen radiograph
4. CT brain
questions.solution: Reference: Jones JG, Mills CN, Mogensen MA, Lee CI. Radiation dose from medical imaging: a primer for emergency physicians. West J Emerg Med. 2012 May;13(2):202-10. doi: 10.5811/westjem.2011.11.6804. PMID: 22900113; PMCID: PMC3415811.

questions.text: What is fMRI?
questions.solution:
Functional MRI is non-invasive MR technique to map or localize brain areas which are responsible for a particular task. The patient is asled to perform a parituclar task and T2* WI are acquired. The area responsible for the activity shows increased signal. It is based on the concept of blood oxygen level dependent (BOLD) imaging.

Reference: MRI made easy page no 190.

questions.text: For deeper penetration, which type of probe is used in USG?
questions.solution:
Low frequency usg waves have higher penetration hence used for imaging of deep structures. However they have low resolution.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medial imaging page 155

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for MRI?
questions.solution:
Although all of the above are contraindications of MRI, metallic implants are a relative contraindication while others are absolute contraindications for MRI scanning.

Reference: MRI made easy page 86

questions.text: A patient who sustained a RTA was brought to the emergency department. He underwent a HRCT chest which shows the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows ill defined areas of ground glass opacity. In presence of history of trauma one should always keep in mind the possibility of bleeding into the alveoli, giving rise to contusions.

which is shown as areas of ground glass opacities on HRCT thorax images.

All other three are pleural pathologies.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2492

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The given image shows interstitial septal thickening, honeycombing which is present predominantly in subpleural locations. There is no evidence of subpleural sparing or ground glass opacities. This all findings favor a diagnosis of UIP(usual interstitial pneumonia). In contrast NSIP(non-specific interstitial pneumonia) shows ground glass opacities, interstitial septal thickenign with subpleural sparing.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1066

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given xray
questions.solution:
The given image shows enlarged lymphnodes on CXR which is seen in the distribution of lambda sign. This helps in diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Along with lambda sign other findings that help in diagnosis of sarcoidosis is panda sign(increased uptake in gallium 67 scan) and calcified lymphnodes.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1074

questions.text:
A preterm patient presented with sudden onset of tachypnea and decreased saturation and underwent a CXR which is shown below.


Identify the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows white-out lungs which are typically seen in hyaline membrane disease. This occurs due to surfactant deficiency which occurs in preterm neonates. If a term neonate presents with difficulty in breathing then a diagnosis of transient tachypnea should be considered however very rarely it shows a white-out lung as described above.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1469

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given xray
questions.solution:
The given image shows a finger in glove appearance of aspergillosis. This occurs due to mucus plugging of the airways which leads to an opacity along the brochi giving a finger in glove appearance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2339

questions.text:
Given below is a barium study image.


What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is of Ileoceacal junction. In the image there is narrowing of terminal ileum giving a string like appearance of terminal ileum. This findings help in diagnosis of abdominal Tb.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1792

questions.text:
Given below is a CXR.


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given xray is of pediatric patient showing coiling of an IFT in the upper thoracic region. In a newborn patient with such coiling of an IFT should lead to a suspicion of tracheo-esophageal fistula.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1084

questions.text:
A patient ingested a corrosive acid followed by which he was hospitalised. After the patient was stabilised and necessary treatments given, the treating physician ordered a fluoroscopic study of the patient for it's further management. Given below is a fluoroscopic study,


what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dye passing into the oseophagus. There is also opacification of the trache and bronchial tree. This finding along with the history of corrosive posioning sholu lead to a suspicion of traumatic tracheo-esophageal fistula

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1084

questions.text: A patient presented with a complaints of abdominal pain usually after meals especially after eating heavy food or fatty food. What is the best investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms point to biliary colic. This occurs due to presence of stoned in common bileduct. The IOC and best investigation in such patients is USG

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2013

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a surgical emergency?
questions.solution:
The presence of free gas under a diaphragm is suggestive of intestinal perforation. IN such patients the treatment is exploratory laparatomy with repair of the perforation. Thus free gas under a diaphragm is considered a surgical emergency.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2122

questions.text: Comb sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Crohn's disease is an inflammotory bowel disease. In this disease, there is involvement of whole GIT especially the small bowel loops. The inflammation leads to stretching of the mesentry and mesentric vessels which gives a comb like appearance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1787

questions.text:
A newborn child presented with complaints of vomiting after meals and inability to gain weight. Following image is seen on screening USG of the abdomen.


What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is an USG image of the abdomen showing a thickened pylorus and narrow pyloric canal. This gives an appearance of an antral nipple sign which is suggestive of pyloric stenosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1090

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for calculous cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
USG is the IOC for calculus cholecystitis as it shows gall bladder calculus easily by demonstrating the posterior acoustic shadow and edematous wall of the gall bladder; suggestive of inflammatory process.


Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2013

questions.text: LI-RADS scoring is based on which investigation?
questions.solution:
LIRADS scoring is used in hepatic lesions. LIRADS scoring is used in such lesions to characterize the hepatic lesions into benign and malignant and to assess the risk of developing into HCC. It is based on MRI.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1927

questions.text:
A middle aged male patient presented with an abdominal lump in the hypogastric region. ON CT scanning the following image is obtained.


What is the most probable primary for the given lesion?
questions.solution:
The given imaeg shows a mass in the abdomen in para aortic region which is heterogenously enahncing. This is most probably a lymhnodal mass. In male patients with pre and paraaoritc lymhnodal mass, the most common primary to be suspected is testicular tumors.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 447

questions.text: Identify the investigation being done here.
questions.solution:
Given above is an CT image of the patient. In the above given image, there is presence of contrast material within the ureters as they are seen white/ radio-opaque. This type of investigation is known as CT IVP in which the kidneys and bladder is mainly visualised.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 6

questions.text:
A patient presented to OPD with painless hematuria and weight loss. He underwent a CT IVP study which is shown below.


What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a CT scan study of the kidneys. It shows a lesion in the kidneys which is expansile and heterogenously enhancing in characteristic. This findings along with the history of hematuria and weight loss points to malignant mass lesion of the kidneys.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 125

questions.text:
A patient presented with difficulty in micturition. He underwent an XRAY which is shown below.


Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Given xray shows a well defined radio-opacity in pelvis. According to patient complaints of hematuria and poor stream of urine, it suggests some pathology blocking the outflow of urine from the bladder. Thus the most probable diagnosis is urinary bladder calculus.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 200

questions.text:
A patient presented with decreased stream of urine and a history of intermittent catheterisation for block in flow of urine. He underwent a RGU examination.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is of RGU which shows thinning of urethra. This along with a history of intermittent catheterisation points to a diagnosis of stricture in urethra. RGU is used for evaluating anterior urethra.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 211

questions.text:
A patient suffered a RTA and following image was obtained on CECT of the patient.


What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a CT scan image of the pelvis. IN the image there is contrast filled bladder and the arrow shows extravasation of contrast into the surrounding structures. This occurs in presence of urinary baldder injury. This shows an extraperitneal bladder injury as the contrast pools surrounding the bladder. In intraperitoneal rupture there is evidence of contrast leakage into the peritoneum which is evidenced by contrast into the peritoneal cavity and ascites.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 457

questions.text:
A patient presented to emergency department with sudden onset of headache and vomiting. On examination his BP was found to be 200/110. He underwent a NCCT brain which is shown below.

Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Given is an NCCT image of brain. It shows a haemorrhage in the brain parenchyma which is hyperdense on CT. This shows an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 118

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above image shows an MRI image of the brain. It shows multiple ring enhancing conglomerated lesions (tuberculoma) in the brain predominantly in the basal region(known as basal exudates). This is suggestive of tuberculosis infection of the brain.

Ther conditions showing ring enhancing lesions are active lesion of MS, NCC.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 377

questions.text:
A child presented with seizures. On examination there was a discolouration on his face which is shown in the image below.


He underwent a CT brain which is shown below. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The given image shows a portwine stain of the face. The CT scan image shows calcification of the brain parenchyma. The facial feature + brain findings + history helps in diagnosis of the child as sturge weber syndrome.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 1279

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient presented with acute onset of breathlessness and difficulty in doing routine work. He was advised to undergo CXR which is shown below.


What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given xray shows opacities predominantly in perihilar region giving a bat wing appearance, this findings point to pulmonary edema. Chronic hypertensive patients are predisposed to heart failure which lead to pulmonary edema.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2278

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Given xray shows a leather bottle appearance of the heart and cardiomegaly which is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2390

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is done to identify a thrombus within the pulmonary vasculature.
questions.solution:
CT Pulmonary angiography is contrast study in which the great vessels are visualised after contrast injection. This helps in visualisation of thrombus in the vessels. It is seen as contrast filling defect in the vessels.


Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2889

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
This image shows linear flap in the vessel creating a false lumen through which the contrast is passing. In aortic dissection there is a flap like structure which divides the lumen and creates a false lumen within it. Common causes include hypertension, marfan's syndrome.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2411

questions.text:
A patient while playing injured a minor injury to the knee joint. He underwent an MRI examination which is shown below.

What is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Given image is a T2WI of the knee joint. To look for any pathology we always use a T2WI. In this image the fluid is shown as white (hyperintense) between the articular margins. In this image there is presence of fluid between the joint space wish is suggestive of joint effusion.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1417

questions.text: Which of the following condition is associated with the xray shown below?
questions.solution:
Given image shows dextrocardia in the patient. Dextrocardia is associated with many conditions. Among the options given above the most suitable condition is Kartagener syndrome. In Kartagener syndrome there is reduced motility of the cilia. This leads to decreased mucus removal and decrease in movement during embryogenesis. This leads to all the pathological characteristic of the disease- Chronic sinusitis, dextrocardia and bronchiectasis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2301

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a heavily calcified aorta. Aorta is usually not seen on Xrays but in this case due to it's heavy calcification, it is visualised. It shows that there is fusiform dilation of aorta in it's abdominal course. This helps in diagnosis as abdominal aorta.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2660

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Acute infarct are earliest seen on CT scan

Reason: CT picks up edema earlier than MRI.
questions.solution:
Acute infarct is earliest visualised on MRI and not CT. The DWI is the most sensitive sequence to visualise the stroke. This occurs because in tissue affected there is restriction in movement of water molecules which can be easily picked up on MRI. The changes to appear on CT would take 6 hours.

Reference: MRI made easy page 140

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Low frequency probe is used for thyroid gland visualisation.

Reason: Superficial organs are better visualised with low frequency probe.
questions.solution:
In ultrasound probes, with increase in frequency of the probe there is reduced depth penetration and increase in resolution. Thyroid is a superficially located organ. Hence for it's better visualisation we use a high frequency probe whiohc gives us better resolution of the organ.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medical imaging page 155

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: For detection of small pneumothorax a CXR should be taken in full inspiration.

Reason: In full inspiration, as the lung fields are fully expanded small pneumothorax can be easily visualised.
questions.solution:
For detection of small pneumothorax, an expiratory film should be ordered as in expiration lung will be collapsed and contrast between the pneumothorax and lung can be easily identified.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 page 694

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Highly aggressive tumors shows diffusion restriction.

Reason: There is freely moving water molecules within it.
questions.solution:
In highly aggressive tumours there is increased cell density. This leads to decrease in the movement of the water molecules through the brain parenchyma. This leads to diffusion restriction in the region of tumours.

Reference: MRI made easy page 140

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Boot shaped heart is seen in tetralogy of fallot

Reason: It occurs because of left ventricular hypertrophy
questions.solution:
In tetrology of fallot there is hypertrophy of right ventricle. This pushes the apex towards left and upwards. This gives rise to a booth shaped heart seen on a PA chest xray.

Reference : Thoracic Imaging Pulmonary and Cardiovascular Radiology edition 3 page 803

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Air bronchogram sign is seen in consolidation. In consolidation the air in trachea is not replaced by fluid. This leads to it's lucency among a solid background sign giving a bronchogram pattern. This is known as air bronchogram sign

Blunting of CP angles is seen in pleural effusion. This occurs because the fluid in the pleural space gets accumulated in dependent position. In standing position the most dependent position is CP angles thus ot gets blunted.

Crescent sign is seen in pulmonary aspergillosis. This occurs when in a preexisting cavity, there occurs a fungal infection which forms a fungal ball. This moves in the cavity and a lucent area around the fungal ball is seen like a crescent giving air-crescen appearance.

Golden S sign is seen when a carcinoma is obstructing the upper lobe bronchus. The bronhus gets obstructed and leads to collapse of the upper lobe thus producing a S shaped silhoute

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2420, 2337, 2514

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
NF-2:

The following imaging features are seen in NF-2 in brian: 1. meningioma 2. schwannoma- usually arise from the inferior vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve, can also be from the facial nerve 3. ependymoma: usually spinal intramedullary (not intracranial/intraventricular)

Tuberous sclerosis

  • Neurological:
    • cortical/subcortical tubers
    • subependymal hamartomas
    • subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SGCA)
  • Abdominal:
    • renal angiomyolipoma(s)
  • renal cysts:
    • renal cell carcinoma and oncocytomas
  • Thoracic:
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
  • Cutaneous:
    • Ash leaf macules

Sturge weber syndrome

S: seizures, sporadic

T: tram track gyriform calcification; trigeminal territory port-wine stain

U: unilateral weakness (hemiparesis - contralateral to facial nevus)

R: retardation

G: glaucoma, GNAQ gene

E: epilepsy

C: calvarial thickening, choroid plexus enlargement

A: atrophy of ipsilateral cerebral hemisphere

P: pial angiomatosis

S: sinus (paranasal) enlargement

NF-1:

>6 cafe au lait spots evident during one year (prepubertal >0.5 cm, postpubertal >1.5 cm in size) two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma optic nerve glioma distinctive osseous lesion (such as sphenoid wing dysplasia or thinning of long bone cortex with or without pseudoarthrosis) two or more iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules) axillary or inguinal freckling

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 1241-1254, 1279

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Spiral fracture: In this type of fracture the fracture line runs in a spiral manner along the bone

Segmental fracture: In this type of fracture the fracture occurs at two places such that leaving a fractured segment completely separate from the bones

Comminuted fracture: In this type of fracture there is presence of multiple fracture fragments of the fractured bone.

Displaced fracture: In this type of fracture the fracture fragments are displaced and not along the axis of the bone.

Reference: Yochum and Rowe's essentials of skeletal radiology, third edition, volume 1 page 793-951

questions.text: Match the following(Investigation of choice)
questions.solution:
The IOC for galls stone is USG, Acute abdomen is CECT abdomen, Intestinal obstruciton is CECT abdomen and for acute cholecystitis is USG.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2013, 2080

questions.text: Match the following findings on HRCT thorax with their respective diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ground glass opacities- It appears as hazy increased opacity of lung, with preservation of bronchial and vascular margins. Commonly seen in COVID-19 pneumonia

Consolidation-It is seen as a homogeneous increase in pulmonary parenchymal attenuation(whiteness) that obscures the margins of vessels and airway walls sometimes giving air bronchogram appearance.

Honeycombing-The appearance is of clustered cystic air spaces, typically of comparable diameters on the order of 3-10 mm but occasionally as large as 2.5 cm. It is a CT feature of established pulmonary fibrosis and in seen in interstitial lung diseases.

Tree in bud appearance-The tree-in-bud pattern represents centrilobular branching structures that resemble a budding tree. The pattern reflects a spectrum of endo- and peribronchiolar spread of disease including mucoid impaction, inflammation, and/or fibrosis. It is seen in endobronchial spread of tuberculosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1078, 2307, 2318

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Given below is a CT scan image of the thorax. Given arros shows a tubular collapsible structure behind the trachea. This is oesopahgus.

questions.text: Which of the labelled structure is common bile duct?
questions.solution:
Given above is an MRCP image of the hepatobiliary system. IT shows the various structures in the biliary tree. The structures labelled as a. Gallbladder b. Common bile ductc c & d. Pancreatic duct e. Renal pelvis. Thus the structure labelled as b is common bile duct.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 758

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Given image shows an MRI of the knee joint. THe structure points here is posterior cruciate ligament.

Reference: MRI made easy page 121

questions.text: What type of hiatus hernia is shown in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Given image is a barium study of the patient. It shows a part of fundus of stomach seen above the diaphragm. This is known as paraesophageal hernia.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2545

questions.text: Identify the type of procedure being done in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an xray procedure being done. In the procedure the kidneys and bladder are opacified by the contrast material. Thus it is an Xray IVP being done in the image.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 56
